population_specificity: People with epilepsy (231 participants across three RCTs, conducted in the USA and China (Hong Kong)).

study_goal: To examine the effect of mindfulness meditation on occupational functioning and healthcare utilization in individuals with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
results_summary: Participation in mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) was associated with a significantly greater decrease in partial workdays missed compared to the control group. Greater home mindfulness practice correlated with reduced work loss and fewer mental health visits during follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (mean age 39, 56% women).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week MBSR program with home practice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness interventions in improving mental health outcomes (stress, anxiety, depression, burnout) among health professional students.
results_summary: Mindfulness strategies reduced stress (-0.60; -0.97 to -0.22) but showed no significant effects on anxiety, depression, or burnout. The study noted generally poor methodological quality across included trials.
population_specificity: Undergraduate and postgraduate health professional students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how staging depressive disorders can guide psychotherapeutic interventions, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, for specific phases of depression.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy was found to be uniquely suited for addressing the residual phase of depression, demonstrating efficacy in this specific stage of the disorder. The study suggests that staging can help tailor psychotherapeutic approaches to different phases of depression.
population_specificity: Individuals with depressive disorders, specifically those in the residual phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether group-based psychosocial interventions, including mindfulness, improve psychological well-being (depression, anxiety, stress, coping) in adults living with HIV/AIDS.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions showed no significant effects on depression, anxiety, or stress, with very low certainty evidence. No valid measurements of coping were reported for mindfulness interventions.
population_specificity: Adults living with HIV/AIDS, including men and women, homosexual men, and women-only groups.
effective_dosage: 90 to 135 minutes weekly for up to 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and initial efficacy of a Mindful Yoga program compared to a social support condition for managing disease-related symptoms like pain and fatigue in women with metastatic breast cancer.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility through attendance rates and evaluated efficacy outcomes including pain, fatigue, sleep quality, psychological distress, mindfulness, and functional capacity at post-intervention and follow-up points, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Women aged ≥18 with metastatic breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of meditation, mindfulness, hypnosis, and relaxation on vasomotor symptoms and health-related quality of life in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that paced respiration, a mindfulness-related technique, was not associated with a statistically significant decrease in vasomotor symptom frequency. The abstract does not provide specific results for mindfulness alone, focusing instead on broader interventions.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal and postmenopausal women with bothersome vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the five-week YOMI program (combining mindfulness and yin yoga) on perceived stress, worry, and mindfulness in a non-clinical sample.
results_summary: The study found significant effects of the YOMI program in reducing stress and worry while increasing mindfulness, with moderate to large effect sizes sustained at a five-week follow-up. The program successfully facilitated self-directed practice in a group setting.
population_specificity: Non-clinical sample
effective_dosage: 10 content-specific sessions (twice a week for five weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) reduces cognitive reactivity in recurrently depressed patients compared to treatment-as-usual (TAU).
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced cognitive reactivity more than TAU (effect size d = .51), and this reduction appeared to mediate the decrease in depressive symptoms. The study suggests cognitive reactivity may be a working mechanism of MBCT.
population_specificity: Recurrently depressed patients (N = 115).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation and mantra training versus psychoeducation and telephone support in improving diurnal cortisol slope, life satisfaction, and reducing stress symptoms among older female dementia caregivers.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention (IR) showed statistically significant improvements in diurnal cortisol slope and life satisfaction compared to the psychoeducation group (PTS), but not in depression or self-efficacy. Adherence to meditation practice was linked to reduced depression and better stress coping. IR participants rated the program's benefits higher than PTS participants.
population_specificity: Older female dementia family caregivers (n=31).
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of Inner Resources for Stress mindfulness meditation and mantra training (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for managing parenting distress in parents of children with disabilities.
results_summary: Most reviewed papers reported positive effects of MBIs in managing parenting distress and psychological distress, providing preliminary support for their efficacy. The interventions included various approaches, such as standalone MBIs and combined mindfulness with other interventions.
population_specificity: Parents of children with disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a multimodal therapy (including mindfulness) and its combination with aerobic training against aerobic training alone in treating cancer-related fatigue and insomnia in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The multimodal therapy (MT) was non-inferior to aerobic training (AT) and showed exploratory superiority at follow-up. The combined therapy (CT) did not confirm superiority over AT at the primary endpoint but showed benefits at follow-up.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with chronic cancer-related fatigue.
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-week program with various components).
study_duration: 10 weeks of intervention, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a simplified emotion-focused mindfulness (sEFM) exercise against a 5-minute iCBT program and a control group in reducing depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The sEFM group showed a significant reduction in depressive symptoms (PHQ-9) compared to the control group post-intervention, but no significant differences were observed in CES-D or GAD-7. Effects were not sustained at the 6-week follow-up.
population_specificity: 974 participants recruited via a market research company website.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in treating depression among individuals with chronic pain.
results_summary: MBCT showed a significant reduction in depressive symptoms (QIDS-C₁₆ scores) in the per-protocol sample but no significant differences in HDRS₁₇ scores between groups. The study was underpowered due to an early termination, potentially limiting effect detection in some outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain (≥3 months) and comorbid depression (MDD, dysthymic disorder, or depressive disorder NOS).
effective_dosage: 8 sessions (participants completed at least 4 sessions in the per-protocol sample).
study_duration: Data collection occurred between January 2012 and July 2013; exact intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore psychological approaches, including mindfulness therapies, as potential treatments for low sexual desire in women.
results_summary: The abstract highlights renewed interest in mindfulness therapies for low sexual desire but does not provide specific results on its effectiveness. It notes that pharmacological approaches like flibanserin have significant side effects and contraindications.
population_specificity: Women with low sexual desire, particularly those with Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the literature on mechanisms of mindfulness interventions and hypothesize which mechanisms likely apply to women with female sexual dysfunction (FSD).
results_summary: The study found that trait mindfulness and decentering were common mechanisms in general populations, while interoceptive awareness, depressed mood, and trait mindfulness were significant mediators in women with FSD. Interoceptive awareness had the most supporting evidence for improving sexual functioning.
population_specificity: Women with female sexual dysfunction (FSD), including those with gynecologic cancer, a history of sexual abuse, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, and provoked vestibulodynia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a mindfulness-focused video to nutrition education improved food-purchasing knowledge, self-efficacy, and behavior among Latinas responsible for household grocery shopping.
results_summary: The 2-video group (including mindfulness content) showed greater improvements in self-efficacy, use of shopping lists, and purchase of healthy foods compared to the 1-video group (nutrition-only). The mindfulness intervention demonstrated statistically significant benefits in promoting healthier grocery choices.
population_specificity: Latinas in Los Angeles, California, responsible for household grocery shopping.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved watching 1 or 2 videos).
study_duration: Questionnaires administered before, immediately after, and 2 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on specific biomarkers (cytokines, neuropeptides, and CRP) in healthy subjects and cancer patients.
results_summary: In healthy populations, MBIs increased IGF-1 levels and may enhance stress recovery but had no effect on cytokines. In cancer patients, MBIs showed some effect on cytokine levels, possibly aiding immune system recovery by altering IL-4 and IFN-γ levels.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in mindfulness skills following Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) predict long-term changes in personality traits, particularly neuroticism and conscientiousness.
results_summary: MBCT led to significant improvements in mindfulness skills and, at 15-month follow-up, lower neuroticism and higher conscientiousness. Large improvements in mindfulness skills predicted long-term reductions in neuroticism but not conscientiousness.
population_specificity: 278 participants with recurrent depression in remission.
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up at 15 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of an ALS-specific mindfulness-based intervention in improving quality of life for people with ALS.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life, anxiety, depression, negative emotions, and social interactions for participants in the mindfulness group compared to usual care. The effect size for quality of life was moderate to large (d = 0.89).
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with ALS within the past 18 months.
effective_dosage: 8-week meditation training based on mindfulness-based stress reduction, tailored for ALS.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 2, 6, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the intervening variables, particularly psychological flexibility and mindfulness facets, in Acceptance and Commitment Group therapy (ACT-G) for reducing illness worry in patients with severe health anxiety.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant indirect effects of ACT-G on illness worry reduction, primarily through psychological flexibility and the mindfulness subscale 'non-react.' These effects were small to moderate, supporting ACT's model of change for severe health anxiety.
population_specificity: 107 patients diagnosed with severe health anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week mindfulness intervention could reduce psychological distress in university students during exams, improve resilience, decrease mental health service use, and enhance academic performance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as the study is pre-results, but it outlines the planned outcomes and rigorous methodology to assess mindfulness's effects.
population_specificity: University of Cambridge students free from active crises or severe mental illness.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up assessments up to 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a group-based adapted mindfulness program for people with mild to moderate dementia in care homes and assess its feasibility and potential benefits.
results_summary: The intervention showed a significant improvement in quality of life compared to controls but no significant changes in mood, anxiety, cognitive function, stress, or mindfulness. The program was feasible in terms of recruitment, retention, and acceptability.
population_specificity: People with mild to moderate dementia in care homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of the mind sound resonance technique (MSRT), a yoga-based mindfulness relaxation, on stress, sleep quality, cognitive function, anxiety, psychological distress, and fatigue among female teachers.
results_summary: The MSRT group showed significant reductions in perceived stress, state and trait anxiety, psychological distress, and fatigue, along with improvements in sleep quality and self-esteem. The control group exhibited worsening in most variables, highlighting MSRT's benefits.
population_specificity: Female primary school teachers aged 30-55 years in Bangalore, India.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an online intervention incorporating mindfulness, alongside a very low-carbohydrate ketogenic diet and other lifestyle factors, could improve glycemic control and weight loss in overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the intervention group, which included mindfulness as part of a broader lifestyle program, showed improved glycemic control and greater weight loss compared to the control group following a conventional low-fat diabetes diet. However, the specific contribution of mindfulness to these outcomes was not isolated or detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (BMI ≥25) with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psychological support, including mindfulness-based exercises, improves acceptance and adherence to non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in COPD patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding mindfulness's effects, as it describes a planned study rather than completed findings. The study design suggests mindfulness will be part of a broader psychological intervention to enhance NIV adherence.
population_specificity: 150 COPD patients for whom NIV is indicated.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness included in a brief course of psychological support).
study_duration: Four to eight meetings (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze studies evaluating mindfulness treatments for substance misuse to assess their methodological characteristics and substantive findings.
results_summary: Mindfulness treatments showed significant small-to-large effects in reducing substance misuse frequency and severity, craving intensity, and stress severity, and were effective in increasing posttreatment abstinence rates for cigarette smoking compared to alternative treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance misuse issues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how mindfulness interventions, alongside parent skill training, could reduce parental stress and indirectly improve behavioral outcomes in children with intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness interventions reduced parental stress and created indirect benefits for children's behavioral competencies, supporting a family-focused developmental systems approach.
population_specificity: Families of children with intellectual disabilities (IDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yoga therapy, including mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), improves physical and psychosocial quality of life (QoL) in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that yoga therapy significantly improved psychosocial outcomes (anxiety, stress, depression, social functioning) and physical outcomes (salivary cortisol, sleep quality, lymphocyte apoptosis), with overall QoL benefits linked to the interventions.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) could reduce stress-related biomarkers (ACTH and pro-inflammatory cytokines) in adults with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
results_summary: MBSR participants showed significantly greater reductions in ACTH and inflammatory cytokines compared to the control group, suggesting MBSR may enhance stress resilience. The study provides combined hormonal and immunological evidence supporting MBSR's efficacy in reducing stress markers.
population_specificity: Seventy adults diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of mindfulness-based psychosocial interventions for bipolar disorder (BD) across different stages of the illness, aligning with recovery-oriented clinical trends.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-based interventions show promise across early, middle, and late stages of BD, emphasizing quality of life and personalized recovery goals. It highlights the need for innovative psychosocial treatments tailored to illness stages.
population_specificity: Individuals with bipolar disorder (BD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) improves mental health, quality of life, and immune function in chemically pulmonary injured veterans.
results_summary: MBSR significantly improved mental health and health-related quality of life compared to the control group. It also increased lymphocyte proliferation and IL-17 levels, though it did not significantly affect CD4+, CD8+, or NK-cell percentages.
population_specificity: Male pulmonary injured veterans with chronic pulmonary and psychological problems due to mustard gas exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize randomized controlled trials (RCTs) evaluating the efficacy and safety of mindfulness meditation (MM) interventions for smoking cessation, reduction, or decreased nicotine cravings.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation did not significantly differ from comparator interventions in effects on tobacco use, with no serious adverse events reported. The evidence was low-quality, and study designs varied considerably, limiting definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Smokers seeking cessation or reduction interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) training on the mental health of medical students during clinical clerkships.
results_summary: MBSR led to small reductions in psychological distress and dysfunctional cognitions, moderate increases in positive mental health, life satisfaction, and mindfulness skills, but no significant effect on physician empathy compared to clerkships as usual over 20 months.
population_specificity: First-year medical students during clinical clerkships at a Dutch university medical center.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly two-hour sessions (didactic teaching, meditation exercises, and group dialogues).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Cognitive-Behavioral Group Therapy (CBGT) and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on self-views in patients with social anxiety disorder (SAD).
results_summary: Both CBGT and MBSR reduced negative self-views and increased positive self-views in SAD patients. Improvement in positive self-views predicted symptom reduction in both therapies.
population_specificity: Unmedicated patients with social anxiety disorder (SAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Interventions on reducing stress and improving mental health in health and social care undergraduate students.
results_summary: Short-term benefits related to stress and mood were reported, though most studies used condensed curricula. Gender and personality were identified as potential influencing factors, but long-term follow-up is needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Health and social care undergraduate students (medicine, nursing, psychology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to evaluate the potential benefits of yoga, a mindfulness-based intervention, for chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: Yoga showed benefits in reducing state anxiety and depression, with modest but statistically significant improvements. Non-significant improvements were noted for balance, trait anxiety, and overall quality of life.
population_specificity: Chronic survivors of stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a mindfulness-based group intervention (Kg-Free) in reducing weight self-stigma, unhealthy eating patterns, and improving quality of life in women with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The Kg-Free intervention significantly improved health-related quality of life, physical exercise, and reduced weight self-stigma, unhealthy eating behaviors, BMI, self-criticism, weight-related experiential avoidance, and psychopathological symptoms compared to the control group. Self-compassion showed a trend toward significance, but no significant between-group differences were found for mindfulness.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-55 with BMI ≥25, without binge-eating, seeking weight loss treatment.
effective_dosage: 10 weekly group sessions plus 2 booster fortnightly sessions, each lasting 2.5 hours.
study_duration: Approximately 14 weeks (10 weekly sessions + 2 fortnightly booster sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a compact mindfulness program as part of early comprehensive rehabilitation on physical function, mental health, and other outcomes in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the mindfulness program's effects, as it describes the study protocol rather than outcomes. The primary and secondary outcomes will measure physical function, mental health, anxiety, depression, sleep, pain, and muscle endurance.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) from two clinical sites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critique existing theoretical models of mindfulness applied to chronic pain and assess the evidence for mindfulness-based mechanisms, particularly psychological flexibility.
results_summary: The review found partial support for the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in chronic pain but highlighted theoretical challenges, including unclear mindfulness constructs and limited evidence for mechanisms. It suggested further integration of mindfulness constructs to improve future treatment development and evaluation.
population_specificity: Individuals with any type of chronic pain.

study_goal: To assess the feasibility and preliminary clinical utility of an 8-week mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) program for adolescents with chronic pain and functional somatic symptoms.
results_summary: The MBSR program showed significant improvements in functional disability, symptom impact, and anxiety, with 83% completion rate and no adverse events. Home practice time correlated with better outcomes, and qualitative feedback highlighted benefits like social support and improved daily functioning.
population_specificity: Adolescents with widespread chronic pain and functional somatic symptoms.
effective_dosage: 8-week MBSR program (specific session frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of mindfulness training in promoting health and wellbeing among first-year college students.
results_summary: Participation in the mindfulness intervention was associated with significant increases in life satisfaction and significant decreases in depression and anxiety, with marginally significant improvements in sleep issues and alcohol consequences.
population_specificity: 109 first-year college students (66% female, 50% Caucasian) recruited from residential halls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of yoga interventions for improving psychological and physical outcomes in children and adults undergoing cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found consistent improvements in psychological outcomes (e.g., depression, distress, anxiety) and some evidence for enhanced quality of life and reduced fatigue. Further research is needed to confirm effects on physical symptoms and stress/immunity biomarkers.
population_specificity: Children and adults undergoing cancer treatment (excluding hormone therapy-only samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing seizure frequency in adults with psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that 82% of participants who completed psychological treatment, including mindfulness, experienced a reduction in seizures of at least 50%. Mindfulness was one of several interventions reviewed, but specific efficacy data for mindfulness alone were not isolated.
population_specificity: Adults with psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) could effectively improve ADHD symptoms, neuropsychological performance, and related outcomes in college students.
results_summary: MBCT participants showed greater treatment response rates (57%-71% vs. 23%-31%), reduced anxiety and depression, increased mindfulness, and improved neuropsychological performance compared to the wait-list group.
population_specificity: College students (ages 19-24) diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a mindfulness-based weight-loss intervention versus an active control on self-reported sleep quality in adults with obesity.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement in sleep quality from mindfulness compared to the control. However, within the mindfulness group, more meditation practice time was associated with improved sleep quality at 6 months.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (BMI 30-45 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a mindfulness-based stress prevention training (MediMind) on distress, coping, and psychological morbidity in medical students compared to Autogenic Training and a control group.
results_summary: The study found no significant interaction effects on distress or coping measures, but a significant overall interaction effect on psychological morbidity (BSI) was observed, though post hoc analyses were not significant. MediMind showed potential to decrease psychological morbidity, but high and selective dropout rates limit generalizability.
population_specificity: Medical or dental students in their second or eighth semester.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore clinical and psychological moderators of the effect of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on pain intensity in women treated for breast cancer with persistent pain.
results_summary: Attachment avoidance was a significant moderator, with higher levels predicting a larger MBCT effect on pain reduction. Radiotherapy showed a potential moderating effect, though not statistically significant, with smaller MBCT benefits observed in those who received it.
population_specificity: Women treated for breast cancer reporting persistent pain (n=129).
study_duration: Measured at baseline, post-intervention, three, and six months follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of phone-delivered mindfulness training (MT) for improving ART adherence and safer sexual practices in people living with HIV (PLWH).
results_summary: The study is exploratory and does not report final results, but it hypothesizes that MT will improve stress, depressive symptoms, and impulsivity, leading to better ART adherence and safer sex practices. If successful, a larger RCT will follow to test these outcomes further.
population_specificity: People living with HIV (PLWH) recruited from an HIV treatment clinic.
effective_dosage: 8 weekly phone calls (specific duration per call not mentioned).
study_duration: 8 weeks (with follow-up at post-intervention and 3 months post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review physiological and neurobiological mechanisms underlying mind-body therapies (MBTs), including Mindfulness, and their effects on health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that MBTs, including Mindfulness, have immunomodulatory effects (impacting immune function and inflammation) and neuromodulatory effects (altering brain function and morphology related to attention, learning, and emotion regulation). Functional genomic and neuroimaging studies support these findings, though further validation is needed due to diverse study designs.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Functional Analytic Psychotherapy Therapist Training (FAPTT) on FAP-specific skills, broadly desirable therapist qualities (including mindfulness), and its feasibility in Singaporean therapist trainees.
results_summary: FAPTT participants showed significant increases in empathy, FAP skills, and treatment acceptability post-training, with improvements maintained at 2-month follow-up. The training was deemed acceptable, though cultural compatibility concerns were raised.
population_specificity: Master's in clinical psychology students in Singapore (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of traditional meditation retreats on improving psychological outcomes in the general population.
results_summary: The study found that meditation retreats were moderately to largely effective in reducing depression, anxiety, and stress, and improving quality of life, with large effects on mindfulness and compassion measures. Results were maintained at follow-up, though heterogeneity among trials limited implications.
population_specificity: General population (N=2912 across 21 studies).
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the usage and evidence base of "third wave" therapies, including Mindfulness, and assess their clinical and public health value.
results_summary: The study found that "third wave" therapies, including Mindfulness, have a strong evidence base supporting their clinical and public health value, with increasing usage over time. The abstract suggests these therapies are effective but does not provide specific efficacy metrics for Mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of meta-analyses)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the Integrative Medical Group Visits (IMGV) model, which includes mindfulness, is effective in reducing chronic pain and depressive symptoms and improving pain self-management compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so final results are not yet available, but the goal is to evaluate the IMGV model's effectiveness in reducing pain and depressive symptoms and enhancing pain management skills.
population_specificity: 154 participants with chronic pain, randomized into IMGV intervention (n=77) and usual care (n=77).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of meditation on restoring grey matter volume in healthy individuals and those affected by neurodegeneration.
results_summary: The review found that all 13 eligible studies reported significant increases in grey matter volume in meditators or mindfulness-based intervention groups, though the affected brain regions varied. Preliminary evidence suggests meditation may offset grey matter atrophy related to neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and those with cognitive impairment (neurodegenerative diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a mindfulness-based workplace intervention for increasing resilience to stress among surgical intensive care unit personnel.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased work satisfaction in the intervention group, with no change in the control group. Negative correlations were found between vigor and emotional exhaustion/burnout, and participants reported recognizing their stress response as a key benefit.
population_specificity: Surgical intensive care unit personnel

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness interventions are more effective than treatment as usual or alternative interventions for improving outcomes in individuals with psychosis, based on randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness interventions for psychosis showed significant improvements on multiple measures, though benefits were smaller in well-controlled trials. These interventions provided therapeutic advantages over routine care and, in some cases, other treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with psychosis or schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate client and staff perceptions of a 4-week mindfulness-based intervention adapted for individuals with substance use disorders (SUDs) and traumatic brain injuries (TBIs).
results_summary: Staff and clients reported general satisfaction with the mindfulness intervention, noting its relevance and applicability to the population. No adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with SUDs and TBIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness intervention on emotional, conduct, and social behaviors in adolescents with parental HIV infection in Myanmar.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention significantly improved emotional and conduct behaviors after 6 months but had no effect on social behavior. The positive effects persisted after adjusting for demographic factors.
population_specificity: Adolescents with parental HIV infection in Myanmar.
effective_dosage: Monthly group sessions for 3 consecutive months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based cognitive behavior therapy as a treatment for hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in women.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based cognitive behavior therapy showed efficacy in treating HSDD, though there was a noted paucity of studies assessing its effectiveness compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Adult women with hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a computer-based mindfulness training and investigate complex temporal interdependencies of self-control networks across health-related domains.
results_summary: The study assessed primary outcomes (momentary mindfulness and self-control) and secondary outcomes (habitual mindfulness and self-control) using electronic diaries and laboratory meetings, with effects analyzed via mixed models and network approaches. Results suggested potential benefits, but specific efficacy details were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy undergraduate students at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz, Germany.
effective_dosage: Not specified (computer-based intervention, frequency/details not mentioned).
study_duration: 6 weeks (with 7 weekly laboratory meetings and 40 days of electronic diary assessments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and impact of a comprehensive lifestyle intervention, including mindfulness, on disease-free survival and biobehavioral outcomes in women with stage III breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found high adherence to the mindfulness component, with qualitative data highlighting its importance and meaningful lifestyle transformations. The intervention was feasible, with high attendance and low dropout rates.
population_specificity: Women with stage III breast cancer undergoing radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness was part of a multicomponent intervention).
study_duration: Initial 4-6 weeks during radiotherapy, followed by 12 months of continued intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurofeedback-assisted, technology-supported mindfulness training (N-tsMT) could provide measurable benefits in attention and well-being compared to an active control condition.
results_summary: N-tsMT showed specific improvements in attention (reaction time on a Stroop task) and well-being (reduced somatic symptoms), with effects correlated and most pronounced in highly neurotic participants. However, secondary measures of attention and well-being did not show training-specific effects, and benefits were modest relative to group-based mindfulness training.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling healthy adults
effective_dosage: Daily practice (exact duration per session not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify which factors (demographic, personality, and baseline mindfulness skills) moderate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in reducing emotional distress in patients with diabetes.
results_summary: MBCT was effective in reducing anxiety, depressive symptoms, and perceived stress, with larger effects in women and those with lower extraversion. Men and highly extraverted individuals showed smaller improvements, with high extraverts also experiencing higher dropout rates.
population_specificity: Outpatients with diabetes (type 1 or type 2) and elevated emotional distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore changes in emotional eating in individuals taking the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) program and whether changes in mindfulness predicted changes in emotional eating.
results_summary: Emotional eating scores significantly decreased after MBSR in both studies (p < 0.001). In Study 2, changes in mindfulness were correlated with changes in emotional eating (r = 0.317, p = 0.004), suggesting MBSR may be effective for emotional eating.
population_specificity: General population of individuals taking the MBSR program.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) reduces distress in men with advanced prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in psychological distress, cancer-specific distress, or prostate-specific antigen anxiety between men receiving MBCT and those receiving minimally enhanced usual care. The only exception was a slight increase in the mindfulness skill of observing for the MBCT group.
population_specificity: Men with advanced prostate cancer (metastatic and/or castration-resistant biochemical progression).
effective_dosage: 8-week, group-based MBCT intervention delivered by telephone.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-ups at 3, 6, and 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a second-generation mindfulness-based intervention (SG-MBI) called meditation awareness training (MAT) for treating fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) compared to an active control group.
results_summary: MAT participants showed significant and sustained improvements in FMS symptoms, pain perception, sleep quality, psychological distress, non-attachment, and civic engagement compared to the control group. Non-attachment and civic engagement mediated treatment effects, and daily meditation time predicted positive changes in all outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week program, daily meditation time was a predictor but exact frequency/duration not detailed).
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up assessments at post-intervention and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of a 5-week positive affect skills intervention (LILAC) for women with metastatic breast cancer, comparing online and in-person delivery methods.
results_summary: The LILAC intervention showed good feasibility and acceptability, with participants demonstrating reductions in depression and negative affect by the 1-month follow-up, falling below the clinical threshold for depression. Online delivery was comparable to in-person, suggesting potential for widespread dissemination.
population_specificity: Women with metastatic breast cancer (N = 39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based interventions on psychological and physical health outcomes in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions showed large effects on eating behaviors, medium effects on depression, anxiety, and eating attitudes, and small effects on BMI and metacognition. Therapeutic effects for BMI, anxiety, and eating behaviors remained significant in higher-quality trials, with no additional benefit from higher intervention doses.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults
effective_dosage: Median dose of 12 hours of face-to-face intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the individual and combined effects of mindfulness meditation practice (MMP) and adaptive working memory training on attentional control and worry reduction in high worriers.
results_summary: Combined training (MMP and n-back task) led to continued reduction in worry post-training, with WM training engagement correlating with immediate improvements in attentional control and resilience. Worry decreased over time, suggesting potential benefits of n-back training as an adjunct to clinical treatment.
population_specificity: Non-clinical, randomized sample of high worriers (60 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a theoretical account (Monitor and Acceptance Theory) to explain the mechanisms underlying mindfulness effects on cognition, affect, stress, and health outcomes.
results_summary: The study proposed that attention monitoring improves cognitive functioning but may increase affective reactivity, while acceptance reduces affective reactivity, together explaining mindfulness benefits for negative affectivity, stress, and health outcomes. The theory offers testable predictions for future research.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical/conceptual study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of third wave mindfulness-based cognitive behavioral therapies (CBTs) for depressive or anxiety symptoms in older adults across various physical and psychological conditions.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based CBT showed moderate effectiveness for depressive symptoms (g = 0.55) and a similar effect for anxiety symptoms (g = 0.58), though the latter had large heterogeneity and potential publication bias. Study quality varied, with limited use of active controls and intent-to-treat analyses.
population_specificity: Older adults with depressive or anxiety symptoms across a range of physical and psychological conditions.
